bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 17, 1941

div1.p: Kean thinks that Gorgas did not begin organizing “mosquito brigades” on Feb 4, 1901, the date of Reed's lecture on yellow fever in Havana. He believes that Reed abandoned the B. Icteroides theory, in July of 1900, and was ready to investigate the mosquito theory by August 1.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 17, 1941

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Monday
Nov. 17 1941

div1.p:
The express man brought last
Friday 14th the package containing
Truby's memoir, his letter to me of Aug 2nd
(extracts) Carbons of your letter to him of
Nov. 2nd and your good letter to me of the
10th- Today came the package of
reprints of your Hygeia article which
I am delighted to get- It is much
more impressive printed consecutively
and with its strong blue cover makes
an inspiring appearance. I think
you are very generous to give me
so many of them and I am delib-
erating whether I will send them
off to relatives and friends right away
2
with the compliments of No. 7. at
Christmas a month hence.

I am glad to know that you are
through with your Rheumatism Review.
How you can conduct so important
a magazine as that and give so
much time and thought to the Episode
is more than a one track mind like
mine can comprehend.

I am glad to know that you have
sent off my bunch of papers to
Truby. I had a fine letter from
him this morning in which he
said that he had not yet received
them and was expecting them-
His letter was dated Nov. 10 so he
had them probably last Friday-
You saw didn't you the photostat
3
of G. O. no. 6. Div. of Cuba, Dec. 21 1900
which Gen Ireland got for us-
He sent one to Truby and I think
one to you & gave me one. It is the
order that Walter Reed referred to in
the postscript of his letter to Dr. L.
O. Howard- I am pleased that you
looked up the interesting little
article of Gen. Winter's, with my note
appended, as to the date when Gorgas
began his yellow fever work in
Havana- The statement that he
began it Feb. 4 is manifestly a
slip of Gorgas's pen as that was the
date when Reed read his famous
paper “Etiology of Yellow Fever: An addi-
tional Note” before the Pan Amer Med
Congress in Havana Feb. 4 - 7 1900 with
4
see p. 87
with its eleven Conclusions which,
as I heard Dr. F.F. Russell say, is
remarkable in that not one of them
has been disproved in all the years
since- Gorgas says in his final Report
to Gen. Wood, July 12, 1902 that he
did not believe that mosquito trans-
mission was “even the ordinary way
of transmitting the disease” -(p. 236)
I am very sure that he did not
rush out of the hall where the Con-
gress was sitting and begin to
organize mosquito brigades that day-

He told me the same thing when
I tackled him to support Reed's
paper at the meeting- I went to
Wash. just before the meeting and
wanted Reed to have the backing
of his Confreres.
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
I have read and made comments on
the extra copy of your letter of comments
to Truby of Nov. 2- I agree with them
in the main- There is one error of
Truby of which you overlooked on page
32. vis that Reed had disposed of the
Sanarelli claim when he was in Cuba
in May 1899- I think I wrote you that
he was sent down to investigate an
outbreak of fever at the Cavalry Camp
at Puerto Principe (Camaguery it is called
now)- That was out of my baliwick and
of course out of Gorgas's as his activities
were limited to Havana It was in
eastern Cuba. He soon spotted it as
our old enemy typhoid- I find in
6
my diary that he & Major Arthur came
out to see me on May 4 at Quemados
before he went to make his inspection
So I recommended that Truby omit
that paragraph. I think that the
Preliminary Note shows that Reed
disposed of B. Icteroides in pages 57 &
58 in July 1900 & was ready to take
up the mosquito by Aug 1st The page
numbers refer of Course to the Senate
Doc. no. 822 Yellow Fever- As we have fre-
quent occasion to make reference to
that useful Compilation suppose we
agree hereafter to call it Sen. Doc. Y. F.
See Page 46- Strength of troops in the Dept
I find that you have inserted in your
Questionnaire of Cuba. It was not Dept of
Cuba but Dept. of Province of Havana and
Pinar del Rio-

This is a clumsy title and a con-
fusing one, as it did not include
The City of Havana which was a
separate Military Dept. but did include
Marianao, Guanajay & the other
provincial towns which were in
Gen Lee's command & of which I
was Chief Surgeon whose report is
quoted in p. 46- I have found much
of interest in your questionnaire and
it has sent me off to look up things
several times- Your very natural ques-
tion at Chapter I gave me a sad smile.
There were 192 doctors in the Army in 1898
the same as when I entered the Army in
1884. This was quite inadequate for the
medical service in time of peace
and as the law did not allow any
Ac
K
8
more the deficiency had to be made
up by employing Contract Surgeons
at $125.00 a month. When Volunteer Troops
were raised as in 1898 they brought in
their Volunteer Surgeons with them
some very good some very bad and
many indifferent- We did not get
Reserve Med. Officers until 1908 these
gave us a means of expansion for war
which we did not have in 1898- The
Surgeon General would have been very
happy to take in more men in 1898
if the law allowed, but the Med Corps
was very proud of their high standard.
Well I must stop & begin a letter to
Truby, your letters are always suggestion
and full of interest- Many thanks for the
reprints and cordial regards.
